doesn't stop us wondering, though
(I basically locked myself in a room and implemented a major feature...well 95% implemented)
there were a couple factors. We have a mailing list, but I think most of us never felt comfortable gumming up the others' inboxes
i think the majority are staying
Those that lived in SF are staying in SF. I get the feeling half those in MV are leaving because of visa issues, and other few are going up to SF. Some are staying in MV

every Tuesday dinner @ericflo gave me evil stares until I started to use it

the worst week I think was demo day, we drove down 6 days in a row, but it's typically not bad
W11 folks - how many of you are staying down in MV/PA? I feel like there are only 5-6 companies left down here from S10

During the application process, they mentioned that you really do have an advantage by applying sooner, rather than later. For those that were accepted, how early did you apply? Do you think it made a difference.  (MongoHQ YC Summer 2011 Applicant)

@dgouldin Guesses, wild guesses, that's all everybody's come up with.
balancing carpool, i mean

YC looks for great committed founders, and I think a lot of apps are "last minute" because those groups are working so much on product/startups/etc., they don't spend as much time focusing on the app - just a random thought
you know if your users have busy schedules!
Are there any estimates floating around as to how many apps were submitted this round?

@jdunck it's hard to compare Mtn View with the entire city, the latter varies wildly in price. Even different parts of SOMA are more or less expensive. That said, I think Mountain View is around the same price as the cheapest areas of SOMA, or a bit cheaper.
@jsoncorwin did you find being that far away hindered getting involved at all?
You know what, there's a thought around 'late applicants' and 'acceptance' perhaps

@jasonmccay I think the benefits of applying early are marginal. From talking to a couple of the partners when they were reading W11 apps, most of them seemed like they did most of their app reading after the submission deadline.
is cost of living massively lower in mtn view?
You can't half-ass a startup, but seems clear that you need to be able to accept that something needs to change, too.
@ericflo hehe, that worried me too, but fortunately they asked how our idea actually works
I didn't really start reading it until I felt like I was missing out on stuff.
aka, there was activity that I *might* care about, but I won't know for sure...
it's like a slot machine. Or Schrödinger's cat. I might win this time. I might not. I don't know until I check.
I know, right?
@mlinsey ahh, the follies of revealing how the sausage is made. :)
@iamwil Cool...it is interesting that they mention it because I have talked to some people that were accepted and the consistent story is that they applied at the last minute. :)
well...filling out the app is much easier when you know your users. You end up spending much less time on it.
@jdunck I don't think that's conflicting advice
yeah, us too, we were here and are staying
With our batch, it seems like 2/3 of the companies moved up to SF from Mountain View.
you have to be at the top of your game during YC, so whatever lets you be there, do that
prior to that during the session, it was 3-4 days - the real convenience comes from last-minute events, or office hours
@iamwil I see...thank you for the info!
@flipside as long as it's not a jetpack you should be fine.
agreed with @ericflo - all the partners push that, and we all kind of laugh, and then your head hangs low towards the end

for myself, I've found geography very important ... just like UX, if something's not convenient, it changes how I use it
@rabble unlikely. They're knocking down a wall to make the room even bigger by about 2x.

@flipside kinda like http://klydo.com?
Man I'm pretty curious about what this crazy tech is, haha
Feel free to give me the 'you crazy' star if not...haha
Yeah, it kind of bugs me to hear advice from different people "ideas are easy" and "you have to give your life entirely to (this one, specific) idea".
So founders, how long did it take you to feel confident in your business plan? Coding is so much easier! Heh.
if you had to *give* money to get into YC, would you do it?

@jdunck I think the value of YC is so great that it would be economically rational to pay some amount of money.  However, I wouldn't pay.  

One of the greatest things about YC is how founder-friendly they are. They pick teams because of the founders and they stand by their founders, supporting them even in some edge cases where it wouldn't be in YC's interest. For example, they never pressure you to turn down an early exit if that's what you want to do.  In this hypothetical universe where YC was charging money to enter the program, that essential characteristic would be lost.
@awfy Ha.
@awfy klydo looks cool for social media, we're aiming for Q&A

@awfy Good deal...we make it easy to provision databases for your apps and we do all the behind-the-scenes fine-tuning to make sure that you don't have to worry about data issues and can just focus on development.
We were checking out all the options as we just moved fully from MySQL.
how confident about their applications were alumni? did you feel like you had hit all the marks?
@ericflo oh, you know, to be able to organize any user generated content, personalize/curate content for any user, scale to any size, solve eternal september, and cure cancer
@flipside i'm only exaggerating on one of those claims, i think
@ericflo now the only thing that worries me is if they understand/believe it, because we made some pretty outlandish claims for what our tech can do
@flipside What's the tech?
@ericflo i know, right? i figure it's at least worth an interview to see if we're legit (we are... in theory)
What time roughly did you hear whether or not you were being asked to come to Y Combinator for the interview process?
@awfy From the people that have answered, the times appear to have varied, with acceptance letters hitting before rejection letters.
@flipside not confident at all, haha, we were worried we didn't put enough details in it
@ericflo being well-known in django and leah having a successful exit probably didn't hurt.
(i assume pownce was viewed as qualification for this, too)
@jasonmccay cheers
@flipside not confident at all.
I think I've heard of MongoHQ...
part of that had to do with commitments that finish up this month

I think our big focus is that basically there are a lot of new apps coming out and the trend is definitely towards hosted services in a lot of these apps, so with MongoHQ, we are providing the data service...and everyone needs data.
Yes...but had only been out of beta for a month or so.
@awfy yeah ... we got started publicly in feb-march of last year
@jasonmccay I haven't heard them mention anything about that actually
@ericflo Well...then, I will take that as a good sign.  :)
lots of leverage

Were you guys around then?
Yeah, we've heard of you then :P
I'm pretty surprised you guys are still part-time at MongoHQ
@jasonmccay Even if you don't get into YC, are you guys planning on switching to do it full-time?
yep, plan Bs for us, too.  but YC is a nice plan A
plan b starts tomorrow night ;-)
a week of interviews, 8 hours, 15 minutes each

Question for previous YC guys/gals...have the YC Partners ever talked about ideas that have been done before...like Heroku and, this winter's AppHarbor or in our case, Cloudant (a couple of years ago) and us (MongoHQ)? Does an idea that they have already done before offer a deterrent to future applicants?

@ericflo We have some options out there and would push hard for them to help us get over the hump...but really hanging on to hope for YC just because we think it would be a great experience and we would get to be a part of the community.
but in short, there are some Plan B's
Grabbing and owning any positive news I can get at this point.
~ 1/10 i think
well, preferably plan A =P
i really should start executing my plan B's, but i'm holding out for plan A
indeed
@jdunck I am sure.
ha...indeed.

PG once listed the most common motivations of founders as 1) money, 2) fear of failure, 3) desire to "hack the world".

He also said those motivate by fear of failure were on average more successful than those motivated by money, and those motivated by a desire to hack the world were most successful of all.

what i collected over the years were, yes

uhhuh
example:
and yea, just pick one and go ;-)

Failed search triage - You have a high-value search (or high-value time), and you aren't getting results quick enough.

thanks guys for the answers
conceptual idea = idea
app with user + revenue = proven
proven >>>>>> idea
@dnguyen that's true generally, but for investors, it's a tradeoff.  idea that seems likely to work and is early means lower valuation, bigger win if it pays off.
investors are in the business of weighing risks.
depends on the market size, proven small idea vs risky big idea can be a toss up
any investor, the goal is to get more incoming than out going...so yeah, risk play a factor, but I would lean toward less risk to bring income than more risk to lose more.
@dnguyen what I mean is, more risk = lower valuation = more upside for a given loss.
agree

Question for YC alums...have any YC teams ever added someone to their team during the YC period? For example, if you got a spot with 2 people and then another person joined your team a month or so later? Any precedent for this?
Question: Has anyone used a good startup lawyer, outside of YC lawyers?

@BrettHardin We have used someone locally to us and he has been great. His name is Mike Goodrich and it is a founding partner of Red Mountain Law. During a previous negotiation, it was vital to have him along with us. Great resource.
Bah, fatfingered enter.
Though that probably depends on the co-founder-ness of the person you bring on.
